Authors:
Qiuyuan Yin, Lei Zhu, Di Liu, Shuyi Zhang, Yi-Hsuan Pan,
David M Irwin
Title:
Relaxed Evolution of the Nuclear factor (erythroid-derived
2)-like 2 gene Nrf2 in Old World Fruit Bats (Chiroptera:
Pteropodidae)
Keywords:
Nrf2, frugivorous bats, relaxed evolution, antioxidant
enzyme, low molecular weight antioxidant
Abstract:
Mammals developed antioxidant systems to defend against
oxidative damage in their daily life. Enzymatic antioxidants and low
molecular weight antioxidants (LMWAs) constitute major parts of the
antioxidant systems. Nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)-like 2 (Nrf2,
encoded by the Nrf2 gene) is a central transcriptional regulator,
regulating the transcription, of many antioxidant enzymes. Frugivorous
bats eat large amounts of fruits that contain high levels of LMWAs such
as vitamin C, thus, a reliance on LMWAs might greatly reduce the need
for antioxidant enzymes in comparison to insectivorous bats. Therefore,
it is possible that frugivorous bats have a reduced need for Nrf2
function due to their substantial intake of diet-antioxidants. To test
whether the Nrf2 gene has undergone relaxed evolution in fruit-eating
bats, we obtained Nrf2 sequences from 16 species of bats, including four
Old World fruit bats (Pteropodidae) and one New World fruit bats
(Phyllostomidae). Our molecular evolutionary analyses revealed that a
change in selection pressure acting on Nrf2 gene was probably caused by
relaxed evolutionary constraints on the Nrf2 gene in Old World fruit
bats. In addition, seven specific amino acid substitutions occurred on
the ancestral lineage leading to the four Old World fruit bats, and
computational predictions suggest that three of these seven amino acid
replacements might be deleterious to Nrf2 function. Biochemical
experiments were conducted to examine Nrf2 in Old World fruit bats and
showed that the amount of catalase, which is regulated by Nrf2, was
significantly lower in the brain, heart and liver of Old World fruit
bats despite higher levels of Nrf2 protein in Old World fruit bats than
in insectivorous bats. Our study provides evidence that Nrf2 experienced
relaxed evolution in the Old World fruit bats in compensation to the
increased levels of LWMAs from their fruit-diet.
